results.title: The Organ. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Simon Preston, speaking from the console of the great Harrison organ in Westminster Abbey, tells of the history and construction of the instrument. He explains the simple theory of sound generation, the problems of providing constant air pressure, and the complexities of playing. Works by Mozart, Purcell and others are played.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: The Bassoon
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Education Foundation for Visual Arts and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
The history and technique of the bassoon are explained by Archie Camden, one of the world’s most renowned players of the bassoon. He explains the complex fingering, and demonstrates intonation, staccato playing and trills. Ends with Camden’s famous arrangement of ‘Allegro Spiritoso’ by Senaille.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Education Foundation for Visual Arts and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.description:

results.title: The Clarinet. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, EFVA and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Jack Brymer of the BBC Symphony Orchestra talks about the history of the clarinet. He demonstrates all the instruments which form the clarinet family, from the high E flat to the contra bass, showing how they work and how to play them. Director Muir Mathieson was music director/composer for Sir Alexander Korda’s London films in the 1930s and 1940s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, EFVA and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.description:

Director Muir Mathieson was music director/composer for Sir Alexander Korda’s London films in the 1930s and 1940s.

results.title: Derek Wickens: the oboe
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Derek Wickens, describes the oboe’s complexity and how its tone is generated by its double reed. The history and range of the instrument is described with examples from Dvorak’s “New World” symphony, Richard Strauss’ Concerto for Oboe and Orchestra and part of the Haydn Concerto.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Derek Wickens, describes the oboe’s complexity and how its tone is generated by its double reed. The history and range of the instrument is described with examples from Dvorak’s “New World” symphony, Richard Strauss’ Concerto for Oboe and Orchestra and part of the Haydn Concerto.

results.title: The Piano. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
A study of the expanding technique of pianoforte composition and playing during the 18th and 19th centuries, contrasting the delicacies of a Chopin Nocturne with the enormous complexities of Liszt, Schubert, Schumann, Brahms; many of the other great romantics are discussed and the modern school is touched on.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: Timpani
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Films and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”
A demonstration of the kettle drums, showing the complications of the tuning of each drum to the required pitch. The modern pedal kettle drum has a mechanism for automatic adjustment of the skin. A tuning gauge helps the timpanist to determine his pitch.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Films and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.description:

results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Opens with a brief recapitulation of the history of the instrument. Paul Tortelier with four cellists from the National Youth Orchestra plays the opening of Rossini’s William Tell Overture. The chamber works of Schumann and Brahms are discussed and Tortelier gives insights into how he combines skill, artistry and musicianship as he plays his own Toccata.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group

results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Paul Tortelier, the French cellist and composer, conducts a master-class of four members of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain and instructs them in some of the finer points in the Dvorak Cell Concerto. Tortelier gives a history of cello playing and the film ends with an excerpt from the great Cello Concerto by Lalo.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group

results.title: The Horn. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Ifor James demonstrates the evolution of the horn from the old hunting horn of nearly 300 years ago, through each stage of its development to the orchestral horn and the modern valve horn, which is capable of rapid changes in key called for by contemporary composers. Illustrated with excerpts from Handel, Mozart and Weber.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: The Trombone
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”
Alfred Flaszynski describes the history of the trombone, its development and the technique of playing, illustrated by excerpts from Ravel’s Bolero and George Lohmann’s Posaune Teufel. The problems of selecting each note by the correct use of the slide and the appropriate harmonic series are dealt with in detail.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
